Quickstart¶

Make sure hsvmoment is installed.

Four SV Models¶

The so-called Heston Stochastic Volatility Model(baseline model) [1] in this package refers to following SDEs [2] ,

\[\begin{split}ds(t) &= \mu s(t)dt + \sqrt{v(t)}s(t)dw^s(t),\\ dv(t) &= k(\theta - v(t))dt + \sigma_v\sqrt{v(t)}dw^v(t),\end{split}\]

where \(s(t)\) is the asset price at time \(t\). Refers to Theory for details.

We also denote the baseline model as mdl_1fsv. Besides, there are three extendsions. In summary, we consider four models:

Model

Description

mdl_1fsv

  • baseline model

  • refers to Theory or One-Factor SV

mdl_1fsvj

  • with jump in return process

  • refers to One-Factor SV with jump

mdl_2fsv

  • with volatility consisting of superposition of two Square-Root Diffusions

  • refers to Two-Factor SV

mdl_2fsvj

  • with jump in return process of model mdl_2fsv

  • refers to Two-Factor SV with jump

The calculation of (central) moments and covariances of the four models are implemented in the four subpackages of package hsvmoment respectively as

Model

Subpackage

Modules

mdl_1fsv

hsvmoment.mdl_1fsv

hsvmoment.mdl_1fsv.cmoment hsvmoment.mdl_1fsv.moment hsvmoment.mdl_1fsv.cov

mdl_1fsvj

hsvmoment.mdl_1fsvj

hsvmoment.mdl_1fsvj.cmoment hsvmoment.mdl_1fsvj.moment hsvmoment.mdl_1fsvj.cov

mdl_2fsv

hsvmoment.mdl_2fsv

hsvmoment.mdl_2fsv.cmoment hsvmoment.mdl_2fsv.moment hsvmoment.mdl_2fsv.cov

mdl_2fsvj

hsvmoment.mdl_2fsvj

hsvmoment.mdl_2fsvj.cmoment hsvmoment.mdl_2fsvj.moment hsvmoment.mdl_2fsvj.cov

Moment Computation¶

Take model mdl_1fsv (baseline) as an example, I demonstrate how to use functions provided by the package hsvmoment to compute the (central) moments and covariances, and their partial derivatives with respect to a given parameter.

The nth central moment and moment of return (of the ith interval of length \(h\)) \(y_i\) can be computed as

## Central Moment
from hsvmoment.mdl_1fsv.cmoment import cm, dcm

parameters = {'mu':0.125, 'k':0.1, 'theta':0.25, 'sigma_v':0.1,
  'rho':-0.7, 'h': 1}
# 3rd central moment
cmoment = cm(l=3, par=parameters)
# partial derivative wrt(with respect to) parameter 'k'
dcmoment = dcm(l=3, par=parameters, wrt='k')

## Moment
from hsvmoment.mdl_1fsv.moment import m, dm

# 3rd moment
moment = m(l=3, par=parameters)
# partial derivative wrt(with respect to) parameter 'k'
dmoment = dm(l=3, par=parameters, wrt='k')

Covariance Computation¶

The covariance between two successive returns of power \(l_1\) and \(l_2\), i.e., \(cov(y_n^{l_1}, y_{n+1}^{l_2})\), can be computed as

## Covariance
from hsvmoments.mdl_1fsv.cov import cov, dcov

parameters = {'mu':0.125, 'k':0.1, 'theta':0.25, 'sigma_v':0.1,
  'rho':-0.7, 'h': 1}
# covariance cov(y_n^2, y_{n+1}^2)
covariance = cov(l1=2, l2=2)
# partial derivative wrt(with respect to) parameter 'k'
dcovariance = dcov(l1=2, l2=2, par=parameters, wrt='k')

The corresponding quantities for other models (mdl_1fsvj, mdl_2fsv, mdl_2fsvj) can be computed by using the counterparts within their subpackages.

[1]

Whose exact equation varies according to different authors. One alternative setting is \(dp(t) = \mu dt + \sqrt{v(t)}dw^s(t)\) where \(p(t) = \log s(t)\).

[2]

Stochastic Differential Equations. Notations: \(v(t)\) is the instantaneous return variance at time \(t\), and \(w^s(t)\) and \(w^v(t)\) are two Wiener processes with correlation \(\rho\).

hsvmoment
